replies.context:
How many such studies over the past 50 years have later been proven false? Every generation sees headlines about the results of health studies, many change their lifestyles to protect themselves, then we find out the study was wrong, and the changes were pointless, or even harmful. 

Have you ever read the study which said salt causes heart disease? It is one of the most absurd things ever written, yet to this day, doctors recommend a low-salt diet. 

The study looked at heart disease fatalities by salt intake. Central Africans ate the least salt, and almost none of them died of heart disease. Southern Europeans at the most salt, and had the most heart disease fatalities. The problem is that the median life expectancy in Central Africa was only 34 years when the study was conducted, no one there lived long enough to get heart disease. The country with the highest salt intake, which is Japan, also has the longest median life expectancy.

The study induced heart disease in rats with high levels of salt. The amount needed was the same you would get from eating 100 McDonald‚Äôs hamburgers per day, every day, for months. Any less, and there was no risk increase. Indeed, we now find low salt diets increase heart disease fatality rates.
I'm not going to gamble with the life of my child listening to the likes of you.

Yet you will happily gamble the life of your child listening to the likes of others? As Edgar Allen Poe said ‚ÄúBelieve nothing you read, and only half of what you see.‚Äù This is as much true in science as it is in politics. Currently, 5 out of 6 scientific papers do not provide replicable results (cannot be proven). This means their results are generally engineered to support the theories or beliefs of their publishers, or those who fund these papers.
Actually, low salt diets in otherwise healthy (non-hypertensive) persons result in significantly higher all-cause mortality. That is about all.

context:
Acetaminophen, or 'Tylenol' is by far one of the most dangerous medications ever created.  A couple thousands milligrams, or as few as 6 or 8 pills, can be enough to completely destroy someone's liver.  Every year, emergency rooms are filled with people who have unwittingly overdosed on this seemingly innocuous drug.  Why this continues to be over-the-counter, and freely available to ANYONE, including unsuspecting minors is an ongoing mystery.  

I'm guessing it has something to do with Big Pharma?

replies.context:
The figure of 8 tablets you quote would be applicable to a small child taking them all at once and not an adult. Let‚Äôs leave the fear mongering out of it.
Taking the recommended dose as indicated on the packaging is not going to do you harm. You can overdose on almost any drug if you are too lazy to read the instructions on the packet.

The recommended max daily dose for an adult, over 24 hrs, is 4000mg - or 8 x 500mg pills (i.e.: over the counter, 'Extra Strength Tylenol').  
Take 'em all at once and you could be in trouble.
Just stating the mathematical facts, Cletus.

No, you aren‚Äôt. An adult would almost definitely not cause themselves any harm from taking 4 grams (8 pills) at once. You said 6 or 8 pills can be enough to completely destroy someone‚Äôs liver - that just MIGHT be true in a small child - not an adult. 

From patient.info.com...

Risk of severe liver damage...Based on the dose of paracetamol ingested (mg/kg body weight):
Less than 150 mg/kg - unlikely.
More than 250 mg/kg - likely.
More than 12 g total - potentially fatal.

So, based on the above figures even a very small adult weighing 50kg (110 lb) would need to down at least 15 tablets all at once before they passed the ‚Äúunlikely‚Äù threshold for severe liver damage, and at least 25 tablets to pass into the ‚Äúlikely‚Äù band for severe liver damage. 
A 25kg 8 year old kid who downed 8 tablets in one go - yeah, they might just have an issue - an adult, no. 
Sometimes Google is your friend. 

And I‚Äôm not sure what you were trying to prove in your other post - the doctor‚Äôs quote you gave is related to overdoses - I never said it‚Äôs impossible to overdose - I said it‚Äôs impossible to overdose if you follow the dosage instructions on the packet. Yes, some overdoses are unintentional - largely because people don‚Äôt realise that paracetamol is an ingredient in several different types of cold and flu medications and they unknowingly take too much  at once from various different sources but if they had read the warnings on the packets properly it would not have happened. Seems simple

Did you miss the least line - "450 deaths occur each year from acetaminophen-associated overdoses; 100 of these are unintentional"
There are still quite a few morons who accidentally OD on this, because they are unaware of how dangerous it can be.  I mean it's a common over-the-counter medication, and also combined with hundreds of other OTC meds!  
Which is the salient point of my original post.

You can‚Äôt sanitise life of all risk just because the world has some morons who refuse to do things like read a label on a package of paracetamol or any related products. Literally any OTC painkiller will be lethal if you take enough of it. The world is full of potentially lethal everyday objects that if used correctly are perfectly safe. We don‚Äôt ban morons from driving, or buying chainsaws, knives or even guns.

I don't understand what your problem is.  What I've quoted are facts & widely known issues with this easily accessible drug.  
Do you own shares in Big Pharma?
Shame we don't ban you morons from posting on this site.

No, my problem is with your disinformation. You quoted incorrect figures saying that a single dose of 6 or 8 tablets of paracetamol can destroy your liver - your very statement itself is  inherently inaccurate and shows you have no idea what you are talking about and just made up your ‚Äòfacts‚Äô - for instance,  is it 6 or actually 8 tablets that you consider could destroy your liver? I then posted actual figures that indicate that the figures you gave are simply not true. So you were wrong. 
You now seem to be suggesting that we should ban paracetamol just because some people won‚Äôt read the dosage instructions and warnings on products containing it  and might take too much leading to them harming themselves - which is simply a ludicrous position to take as it could apply to almost every medicine in existence. It also flies in the face of the personal  ‚Äúfreedom‚Äù I am sure you like to endlessly bang on about when given half a chance - if you got your way then morons should be free to buy guns and not wear masks but they won‚Äôt be allowed to buy paracetamol products when they have a cold because they can‚Äôt be trusted to read the labels properly.  Lol.

Dr. Aric Hausknecht MD, a New York neurologist and pain management 
specialist, said this in 2017:
"Tylenol Is By Far The Most Dangerous Drug Ever Made"
"Each year a substantial number of Americans experience intentional and 
unintentional Tylenol (acetaminophen) associated overdoses that can result in serious morbidity and mortality. Analysis of national databases show that acetaminophen-associated overdoses account for about 50,000 emergency room visits and 25,000 hospitalizations yearly.  Acetaminophen is the nation's leading cause of acute liver failure, according to data from an ongoing study funded by the National 
Institutes for Health. Analysis of national mortality files shows about 
450 deaths occur each year from acetaminophen-associated overdoses; 100 of these are unintentional."

Google is sometimes your friend - maybe try it.

There is no link between the two, other than the fact that autism is reliably diagnosable at age 2 and often around 18 months, which is 6-9 months after the first MMR dose is given.  No causal relationship has ever been established and the mountains of evidence we have demonstrates that. Andrew Wakefield (who published the only paper demonstrating a link) only had 12 total children in the study and was retracted because he handpicked children who would show the result he wanted and unethically did invasive tests on them that he was not approved to do. He lost his medical license for that. Since that paper, since its a hot topic, there have been literally thousands of papers on the subject some with massive sample sizes and none have found a meaningful link between the two. It's always sad for a parent to find out their child might be on the spectrum, and they obviously want answers, they want to know "why?". It is no surprise that people hear from a charlatan like Wakefield that there is a link and they believe it because they were looking for a reason. Doesnt change the facts nor the evidence though.
There is no link between vaccines and autisim.

"Is Autism Genetic? Study Finds 80% Risk From Inherited Genes
September 6, 2019
What causes autism?
A new study looking at autism in 5 countries found that 80 percent of autism risk can be traced to inherited genes rather than environmental factors and random mutations. The study, published July 18 in JAMA Psychiatry, analyzed data of nearly 2 million people across Denmark, Finland, Sweden, Israel, and Western Australia. It is the largest family-based genetic autism study to date, including children with autism, their siblings and cousins, as well as parents and their siblings."autismspeaks.org

What was their reason for taking the medication?  Maybe THAT‚ÄôS  what is associated with ‚Äúautism‚Äù. Science never answers questions or makes conclusions (unless it‚Äôs physics). It only provides risk-reward statements. Every scientific article published in a peer review journal ends with qualifiers and cautions about interpreting the results.

replies.context: You realize acetaminophen is tylenol right?

This sort of study is nearly useless. It proves nothing.
Since it relies on self reporting, it could actually show a correlation between maternal memory and autism. Better memory=more autism.
Noting they only reported the main effect, and not the confidence intervals, it may not even be statistically significant.
It may indicate an actual cause and effect exists, and it is an area worthy of additional study.
Like all medications, acetaminophen should be used only when necessary.
For some strange reason, medical research is the weakest of all research. Maybe it is because physicians are not trained as scientists.

replies.context: Ibuprofen is contraindicated in the third trimester because it is associated with a whole host of dangerous syndromes (oligohydramnios with nephrotoxicity, periventricular hemorrhage, premature ductus arteriosus closure). It is relatively save until the 3rd trimester though, unlike Aspirin which is dangerous throughout.
Terrible for your kidneys though.
